results.title: Fear eats the soul = Angst essen seele auf
results.creator_credit: Tango Film, Christian Hohoff and Rainer Werner Fassbinder
results.brief_description: Fear eats the soul is prolific German director Rainer Werner Fassbinder’s unsentimental interpretation of Douglas Sirk’s “All that heaven allows”. In this tough blend of social realism and Hollywood melodrama, Fassbinder examines racism and class in the love affair between an elderly German widow (Brigitte Mira) and a young Arab immigrant (played by Fassbinder’s lover at the time El Hedi ben Salem) which is met with hostility and derision from their family and friends. Considered the leading director of the ‘new German cinema’, Fassbinder had already dealt with this subject matter in his 1970 feature “The American soldier”. Winner of the International critics prize, Cannes Film Festival 1974. In German with English subtitles.

results.title: Faust
results.creator_credit: UFA, Erich Pommer and Friedrich W. Murnau
results.brief_description: Classic silent German cinema from the talented F.W.Murnau, 1926. “The portals of darkness are open and the shadows of the dead hunt over the earth..” opens the film with the prevailing theme of good versus evil as the devil Mephisto does a deal with alchemist Faust for his soul and potentially for dominion over the Earth - promising he will stop the plague that is rife throughout Faust’s village. Faust reneges on the arrangement choosing love - much to the delight of Archangel St. Michael. Based on the original story by Goethe. Great cinematography and effects give the film a dark foreboding and general creepiness that add to the dramatic impact of the work. This edition features orchestral soundtrack by the Olympia Chamber Orchestra.

results.title: Father of the bride
results.creator_credit: Touchstone Pictures, Charles Shyer, Carol Baum, Nancy Meyers and Howard Rosenman
results.brief_description: Steve Martin stars in this fairly rudimentary remake of the Spencer Tracey/Elizabeth Taylor original of 1950, directed by Vincente Minnelli. On her wedding day, the bride’s harried father reminisces over the rocky journey from proposal to ring swapping, for he and his family. Feeling increasingly sidelined by the trappings of the big day, George Banks (Martin) gets in to no end of trouble as he tries to steer his way through the mysterious rites of modern marrying whilst also recognising that his daughter is all grown up. Also stars Dianne Keaton and Kieran Culkin.

results.title: Father of the bride
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Pandro S. Berman and Vincente Minnelli
results.brief_description: Stanley Banks is a secure middle-class lawyer whose daughter, Kay, announces her wedding plans to Bickley Dunstan. From that point on, everything in Stanley’s life is turned upside down. His wife, Ellie, wants Kay to have the kind of formal wedding that she and Stanley never had. In between meeting his soon-to-be in-laws, his man-to-man talk with the groom, hosting the engagement party, financing the increasingly lavish wedding, and wondering if Kay and Buckley will resolve their differences before arriving at the altar, Stanley barely has time to deal with his own considerable anxieties about his advancing age and how his “little girl” became a woman. Cast includes Spencer Tracy, Joan Bennett, Elizabeth Taylor and Don Taylor.

results.title: Fatal attraction
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Stanley R. Jaffe, Sherry Lansing and Adrian Lyne
results.brief_description: Michael Douglas, Glenn Close and Anne Archer star in this gripping, if at times inconsistent thriller. A passionate week-end encounter ends Dan Gallagher’s perfect life. Alex refuses to be a woman scorned and her capacity for revenge and violence is without limit. The conclusion is unforgettably shattering as the nightmare draws to its inevitable “bloody” climax. Glenn Close gives an excellent, terrifying performance as the homicidal Alex as the film grapples with men’s subconscious fears about women.

results.title: Fat pizza
results.creator_credit: Fat Pizza, Village Roadshow Pictures, Paul Fenech and Tanith Carroll
results.brief_description: This Australian comedy, based on the SBS television show “Pizza”, has an irreverent anarchic flavour that is certain to (intentionally) offend. Pauly (Paul Fenech) is a pizza delivery boy who works for the explosively bad-tempered Bobo (Johnny Boxer); Pauly’s other main occupation is to drive about in his souped-up car, with its blaring sub-woofer stereo; meanwhile his friends Sleek (Paul Nakad), and Davo (Jabba) similarly cruise around in their own customised vehicle, encountering violent cops and sexually eager women. Fans of the series will recognise the vigour with which writer Fenech attacks sacred cows of Australian culture - principally, but not exclusively, the young male Lebanese/Australian racial stereotype - whilst applying a thick layer of infantile machismo and t&a humour. Certainly not to the taste of all, but quite original and daring in both concept and execution. Cast also incudes Annalise Braakensiek with cameos by Merv Hughes, Tim Ferguson, Jeff Fenech, Shane Porteous, Red Symons, Bernard King and Kamahl.

results.title: Fat girl = For my sister = A ma soeur! [DVD] (E)
results.creator_credit: Arte France, CB Films (France), Flach Film, Immagine e Cinema (IT), Urania Pictures, Jean-Francois Lepetit and Catherine Breillat
results.brief_description: Catherine Breillat (Romance, 36 fillette) courts controversy with this starkly compelling coming of age film. Anais (Anais Reboux) is a depressed and overweight thirteen-year-old girl who lives in the shadow of her beautiful and sexually alluring fifteen-year-old sister, Elena. On holiday with their aloof mother and apathetic father, the sisters meet Fernando, a handsome Italian law student who forms an instantaneous attraction to Elena. Elena is aware of her appeal, although naive about the manipulations of men, and yearns to lose her virginity with someone she loves. Fernando, an experienced sexual predator, sets about conquering Elena through coercion, flattery, guilt inducing overtures and the weight of his experience. Whilst Elena vacillates between acquiescence and resistance, Anais is a mute and unwilling witness. As well as displaying in a confronting manner the deflowering of Elena, Breillat also explores the complex relationship between the sisters that oscillates between abuse and affection, displaying several scenes in which they compare their morality and opposing perspectives about love and sex. Breillat successfully interrogates her subject matter of the abject adolescent condition in a powerful manner allowing much room for viewer contemplation. But a shock ending that taps into Anais’ wish-fulfilment in a most brutal fashion, divided audience and critical reaction. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Fast, cheap & out of control = Fast cheap and out of control [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Errol Morris and Fourth Floor Pictures
results.brief_description: Fast, cheap & out of control is another ‘non-fiction’ film from acclaimed director Errol Morris. It continues his highly imaginative and inventive exploration into the relationship between the individual and society. Four men are interviewed in this documentary, and are identified more according to their extraordinary, eccentric obsessions then anything else. They include: a lion tamer (Dave Hoover), a topiary gardener (George Mendonca), a mole-rat specialist (Ray Mendez) and a robot scientist (Rodney Brooks). Once again, Morris succeeds in presenting us with well-chosen, highly articulate characters who, in a relaxed manner, discuss the origins of their passion and reflect on its importance today. Despite their eccentricities, Morris refrains from judging or mocking each character and instead is even-handed and respectful. As they discuss their obsession, each reflects on philosophical matters that range from evolution, the Other, survival to life and death. Morris reveals how these obsessions reflect not only their personalities and values but also elemental emotions and thoughts: fear and survival for the lion tamer; nature and its human manipulation for the topiary; the Other and the act of confronting something completely foreign for the mole-rat specialist; and the interface between machine and man, technology and life for the robot scientist. Morris interweaves early cinema footage with present-day material in a dreamlike, musical manner that emphasises the connections between each individual’s obsessions. Ultimately, what these individuals obsessions come to represent is less an eccentricity or weirdness and much more an act of attempting to come to a genuine understanding of the world, society and human life.

results.title: Fast times at Ridgemont High [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, Art Linson, Irving Azoff and Amy Heckerling
results.brief_description: ‘Fast times at Ridgement High’ is the seminal “teen” movie, one that finds a balance between the obligatory sex and drugs, as well as dealing with issues such as juvenile delinquency, strict teachers, underage sex and teen pregnancy. At the centre of the film are siblings Stacy (Jennifer Jason Leigh) and Brad (Judge Reinhold), Stacy is quickly learning about men and sex while Brad lusts after her best friend and gloats about his career prospects. Supporting characters include theatre usher Rat (Brian Backer) who has a crush on Stacy, and Rat’s friend Mike Damone (Robert Romanus) - a smooth talking sleaze. With dialogue that does not progress much beyond expressions such as “no way”, Sean Penn steals the limelight as the definitive surfer dude Jeff Spicoli - spinning a legion of imitators in subsequent films. Based on the book by Cameron Crowe.

results.title: Fast talking
results.creator_credit: Old Data, AFI [au], Ross Matthews and Ken Cameron
results.brief_description: An Australian feature film that presents the story of fifteen year old Steve Carson, a con artist, spirited rebel and determined survivor in the face of crumbling family relationships. The many influences in his life are highlighted in a comedy of fast dialogue and outrageous escapades. Starring Rod Zuanic, Toni Allaylis, Chris Truswell, Gail Sweeny and Steve Bisley.
